items.title: FIIs boost holdings in state-run banks in the September quarter. Is the smart money betting on a breakout?
items.description: Foreign investors are boosting their holdings in Indian public sector banks. This move signals growing confidence ahead of potential government policy changes. An increase in foreign ownership limits could unlock significant capital. Analysts see this as a positive development for the banking sector. The September quarter data shows a clear trend of renewed FII interest in these lenders.

items.title: Rekha Jhunjhunwala buys 1 crore shares of multibagger PSU stock after Federal Bank, Titan Company in Q2
items.description: Ace investor Rekha Jhunjhunwala significantly boosted her stake in Canara Bank, acquiring an additional 1 crore shares. This move aligns with positive market sentiment for PSU banks, potentially driven by increased foreign investment caps. Jhunjhunwala also increased her holdings in Federal Bank and Titan Company, underscoring her continued confidence in India's financial and consumption sectors.

items.title: Banks tap Fed Standing Repo Facility in record numbers amid month-end pressures
items.description: The Federal Reserve's Standing Repo Facility loaned a record $50.35 billion on Friday to address month-end liquidity pressures in short-term funding markets. Two operations saw the facility lend $30 billion and $20.35 billion, respectively, to eligible financial firms facing temporary cash needs.

items.title: Wall Street Week Ahead: Resilient stocks rally faces earnings wave after AI, Fed wobbles
items.description: Indian markets are watching a strong US stock rally. Investors are focused on upcoming company earnings and the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions. The market is at high valuations, making earnings crucial for future gains. The first week of November is historically positive for stocks. AI investments are a key theme, with companies announcing spending and investors seeking returns.

items.title: 5 world market themes for the week ahead
items.description: Markets face a crucial November. The U.S. government shutdown impacts economic data. Central banks in the U.S., Europe, and Japan are making key decisions. The Bank of England's meeting could bring significant market moves. Oil prices remain uncertain. Australia's inflation data complicates interest rate outlooks. Investors watch for market shifts.

items.title: Fed's Waller calls for December rate cut, as hawks press for policy pause
items.description: Federal Reserve officials revealed stark disagreements over the recent interest rate cut, with some presidents expressing discomfort and advocating for a pause. Governor Christopher Waller, however, pushed for further easing to support a weakening labor market. This internal division complicates Chair Jerome Powell's efforts to build consensus as the Fed faces a crucial December meeting.

items.title: Wall Street gains on Amazon boost but rate caution tempers enthusiasm
items.description: Wall Street indexes closed higher, led by Amazon's strong earnings forecast, but Fed rate cut hopes dimmed.  Amazon shares surged, boosting the consumer discretionary sector.  However, cautious Fed commentary and supply concerns for Apple tempered overall sentiment, despite strong earnings season performance.

items.title: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang completes $1 billion share sale
items.description: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang has sold over one billion dollars in company shares. This sale concludes a large pre-planned divestment. The chipmaker recently crossed a five trillion dollar market value milestone. This surge is driven by high demand for artificial intelligence processors. Several other company insiders have also profited significantly from the AI boom.

items.title: How will Sebi's changes to banking indices impact investors?
items.description: Sebi is pushing for broader banking and financial services indices, aiming to reduce the dominance of a few large banks. This move will cap individual stock weights at 20% and top three at 45%, potentially benefiting smaller and mid-sized banks. Investors and traders can expect shifts in portfolio rebalancing and new trading opportunities as the indices adapt.

items.title: Shutdown of weekly options not practical, says Sebi Chairman
items.description: India's market regulator Sebi will proceed cautiously on restricting weekly futures and options expiries. Sebi chief Tuhin Kanta Pandey stated an outright shutdown is impractical. The regulator has already implemented measures to control speculative trading by retail investors. Further policy interventions will follow extensive data analysis and public consultation.

items.title: D-Street hits pause on Fed's rate cues; focus turns to trade deal
items.description: Indian equity indices closed lower on Friday, extending weekly declines but logging strong monthly gains. Investor caution stemmed from the US Federal Reserve's stance on interest rates and the US-India trade deal outcome. Analysts suggest current dips present buying opportunities ahead of potential rallies.

items.title: Hold stocks & keep a long-term perspective: 5 mid- and large-cap stocks with proven track record & upside potential of up to 44%
items.description: In a bullish market, investors tend to buy stocks without bothering about fundamentals. In a bearish market, however, they may end up selling promising stocks. But what about a market that is neither bullish or bearish and is waiting for an event risk to pass? Or for something positive to fructify? The India-US trade deal can be a huge positive when it happens. But given that we are dealing with a mercurial US President, it can still turn out to be an event risk. With Trump, no deal is done till it is actually done. Does all this mean we should stop investing in the market? Certainly not. Just be cautious and selective – and keep a long-term perspective.

items.title: ‘Dumb money is chasing dumb IPOs’: Shankar Sharma on India's public markets amid Lenskart buzz
items.description: Veteran investor Shankar Sharma slams India's IPO market as the "dumbest in history," citing Lenskart's pre-IPO activity. He alleges a "beautiful little game" where anchor investors create artificial legitimacy, leading to inflated valuations. Sharma claims companies exploit retail investors' anchoring bias, causing stocks to collapse post-listing, only for investors to be trapped again.

items.title: Concurrent Gainers: 10 BSE500 stocks that gain for 5 days in a row
items.description: During the five trading sessions ending October 31, the Sensex declined by 273 points to close at 83,939, finishing in the red on three out of the five days. Despite the overall market weakness, 10 stocks from the BSE500 index managed to post gains in each of the five sessions. (Data Source: ACE Equity)

items.title: We like their business even if valuations are expensive: DSP Mutual Fund clarifies on investment in Lenskart IPO
items.description: DSP Mutual Fund clarified its investment in the Lenskart IPO amid investor concerns over valuations. The fund house stated it invests only with conviction across business strength, promoters, execution, and valuations. While acknowledging Lenskart's strong fundamentals, DSP admitted retail and e-commerce valuations are currently high, explaining they trimmed other positions to accommodate this investment.

items.title: Morgan Stanley adds RIL, Varun Beverages to its focus list. Here’s why these 2 largecaps made the cut
items.description: Morgan Stanley has updated its India Equity Strategy focus list. Reliance Industries and Varun Beverages are now included. Interglobe Aviation and Jubilant Foodworks have been removed. The firm favors large private sector companies in Financials, Consumer, and Industrial sectors. Reliance Industries' AI and green energy initiatives are highlighted. Varun Beverages' growth potential is also noted.
